node.text:
⚫It was concentrated in what is today Greece and along the western coast of Turkey.
⚫However, ancient Greek colonists established cities all around the Mediterranean and along the coast of the Black Sea.
⚫Ancient Greek civilization flourished from the period following Mycenaean civilization, which ended about 1200 BCE, to the death of Alexander the Great, in 323 BCE.
⚫By that time, Greek cultural influence had spread around the Mediterranean and, through Alexander the Great’s campaign of conquest, as far afield as India.
⚫The civilization of ancient Greece has been immensely influential on language, politics, educational systems, philosophy, science, and the arts.

node.text:
⚫It is a historical and archaeological city in southern Jordan.
⚫By the 2nd century BC Petra was the capital city of Nabataeans kingdom.
⚫Petra is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system.
⚫The Treasury (Al Khazneh) is the most known building in the city.
⚫In 2007, Al-Khazneh was voted one of the New 7 Wonders of the World.
⚫Petra is also called the 'Rose City' because of the colour of the stone from which it is carved.
⚫It has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985.
⚫UNESCO has described Petra as "one of the most precious cultural properties of man's cultural heritage".
⚫Visitor numbers reached 1.1 million in 2019.
Credit : @natgeo

node.text:
(Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore )
⚫Located their in Florence, Italy.
⚫The basilica is one of Italy's largest churches, and its dome is the largest brick dome ever constructed.
⚫The construction begun in 1296 in the Gothic style to a design of Arnolfo di Cambio.
⚫But by the beginning of the 15th century, after a hundred years of construction, the structure was still missing its dome.
⚫In 1436, Filippo Brunelleschi completed the structure by building the dome.
.

node.text:
🔘The Road to The Pyramids🔘
⚫In this Magellantv documentary Professor "Joann Fletcher" goes in search of the building blocks of Egyptian civilization and finds out what made ancient Egypt the incredible civilization that it was.

⚫She travels almost 20,000 years back in time to discover north Africa's earliest rock art, discovers how the first writing was used to calculate taxes and explores one of the first stone structures on earth - Egypt's first pyramid "The Pyramid of Djoser"

⚫Egypt's earliest calendar and how the Egyptians used to align their monuments with the sun and the stars?
⚫It also discusses the beginning of mummification.
⚫The pyramids of Giza and its complete city of workers!
👉To Check out this documentary and more… visit the link in the bio and get a full month for free on "Magellantv"👆
⚫MagellanTV has over 3,000 documentaries to choose from.

⚫ @magellantv  has a rich and varied History content: ancient, modern, current, early modern, war, biography, and other
genres bring the past to life in their own way… like Science and True Crime.

👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

node.text:
🔘Initiation Wells🔘
⚫Located in Sintra, Portugal.
⚫The Palace of Monteiro the Millionaire consists of a palace and chapel with exquisite décor including frescoes, stained glass windows, and lavish stuccoes.
⚫The grounds feature lakes, grottoes, wells, benches, fountains, and an extensive and enigmatic system of tunnels that connect to two spiraling wells.
⚫The pair of wells, known as the ‘Initiation Wells’ consist of ‘winding stair’ architecture, which carries symbolic meaning including the death/rebirth allegory common to many hermetic traditions.
⚫The wells were never used to collect water. Instead, they were part of a mysterious initiation ritual within the Knights of Templar tradition.

👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

node.text:
🔘The Cochem Castle🔘
⚫Located high above the town of Cochem on the banks of the Moselle River in Germany.
⚫The current castle is not the castle that originally stood there in the 12th century.
⚫That castle had a long and colorful history until it destruction in 1689.
⚫The castle remained a colorful stone ruin for 180 years until wealthy Berlin businessman Louis Ravené decided to buy the ruins and rebuild the castle in 1868.
⚫He had his architects create a neo-Gothic castle that could serve as a summer residence for his family.
⚫The original Cochem Castle, perched prominently on a hill 300 feet above the Moselle River, served to collect tolls from passing ships.

node.text:
🔘Shakuson-ji Temple🔘
⚫Located in komoro, Nagano, Japan.
⚫It is famous for a Kannon-do temple hanging on the cliff.
⚫The Kannon Buddha dedicated in this temple is called Nunobiki Kannon who appears in the Japanese legend where the Buddha changed his appearance to a cow and persuaded a greedy old lady to go to Zenko-ji and correct her life.
⚫It was built circa 1100s and designated as an important cultural property.

👉Don't forget to Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

node.text:
🔘The Tomb of Akhenaten (KV55)🔘
(Tutankhamun's father)
⚫It's located in the Valley of the Kings, Egypt.
⚫The tomb was built in the 14th century B.C,
and it has long been speculated that the body found in this tomb was that of the famous Pharaoh Akhenaten.

⚫However, the results of genetic and other scientific tests have confirmed that the person buried there was both the son of Amenhotep III as well as the father of Tutankhamun which is "Akhenaten".
⚫Akhenaten (Amenhotep IV ) was the 10th pharaoh Eighteenth Dynasty.

⚫Akhenaten is noted for abandoning Egypt's traditional religion and introducing Atenism, worship centred on the sun disc god "Aten".
⚫So later rulers referred to Akhenaten as "the enemy" or "that criminal" in archival records.

⚫The 27.61 meters long tomb is relatively small, also it's undecorated, single-chamber tomb.
⚫The tomb appears to be unfinished and later it was heavily damaged due to moisture.

⚫The mummy was badly preserved but its linen wrappings appear to have been intact.

🕵️👉Don't forget to Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

node.text:
🔘The Derinkuyu underground city🔘
⚫It is an ancient multi-level underground city in the Derinkuyu district in Cappadocia region, Turkey.

⚫There are 36 underground cities in Cappadocia and the deepest one is "Derinkuyu underground city".

⚫It's consists of 18 levels ,extending to a depth of approximately 60 metres (200 ft) , each level connected to the next level by a hallway with a stone door.

⚫Now only 8 are open to the public.
⚫It is large enough to have sheltered as many as 20,000 people together with their livestock and food stores.

⚫It contains (stables, cellars, storage rooms, kitchens, churches, rockcut tomps ,wineries etc.)
⚫Apart from these, a large room with a barrel vaulted ceiling on the second floor was a missionary school, on the left there's some study rooms.

⚫It is clear that the people planned to be completely self-sufficient.
🌬More than fifty ventilation shafts brought in air from above, while thousands of smaller ducts distributed that air throughout the entire city.

⚫The age of Derinkuyu and who built it are uncertain.
⚫Thus, if the Hittites built it, as a number of scholars believe, it may have been well before 1200 BCE.

🌬Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvelous History.❤

node.text:
🌊Pavlopetri 🌊
⚫It's a submerged ancient town located in southern Laconia, Greece.
⚫It is the oldest complete town ever found underwater; is believed to have flourished in the period between 3000 and 1000 years BC.

⚫A combination of earthquakes and sea-level rise caused Pavlopetri to sink.
⚫The 1968 project recovered a small amount of finds from the seabed (mainly pottery but also obsidian and chert blades and a bronze figurine).

⚫They produced a plan of a prehistoric town, thought to be Mycenaean, covering an area of about 300m by 150m, lying in one to four metres of water.

⚫At least fifteen separate buildings (consisting of a series of rooms), courtyards, streets, two chamber tombs and at least thirty-seven cist graves were identified.

node.text:
🔘Prisoners and slaves🔘
⚫In this "Magellantv" documentary "Mary Beard" reaches back to the myths and legends of the origins of Rome to gain an insight into the deep-rooted psyche of the people of Rome.
⚫The tale of Romulus and Remus the two babies who were saved by a wolf and why did Romulus murdered his twin brother?
⚫From the very beginning, Rome was also an asylum for outcasts and exiles and because of this, it adopted a uniquely inclusive approach towards its neighbours and defeated enemies.
⚫What the submerged artefacts tells us about the history of Rome?
⚫She also discuss the conflict between Julius Caesar and Pompey and its subsequence!
👉To watch this documentary and more… visit the link in the bio and get a full month for free on "Magellantv"👆
⚫@magellantv has over 3,000 documentaries to choose from.

⚫MagellanTV has a rich and varied History content: ancient, modern, current, early modern, war, biography, and other
genres bring the past to life in their own way… like Science and True Crime.

👉Follow me @ancient.scientist to enjoy more and more posts about our world's marvellous History.❤

node.text:
🔘Boscawen-Ûn stone circle🔘
⚫Located in Cornwall, UK.
⚫The stone circle at Boscawen-ûn is considered to be one of Cornwall's most popular prehistoric ceremonial centres.

⚫The stone circle consists of a central standing stone encircled by 19 other stones, including 18 made of grey granite and one of bright quartz.

⚫The oval circle has diameters 24.9 and 21.9 metres (82 and 72 ft).
⚫There is a west-facing gap in the circle, which may have formed an entrance.

⚫The large central stone has a feet 👣or axe⛏️ petroglyph.
⚫These engravings are unusual in the United Kingdom, though they can also be observed on some of the stones at Stonehenge.

node.text:
🔘The Royal Kurgan🔘
⚫It dates back to the 4th century BC, and located in eastern Crimea.
⚫The burial is located in the present-day Kerch, which developed out of the ancient Greek town Panticapaeum founded by Miletus.

⚫The mound is almost 20 metres high and its base perimeter is about 250 meters.
⚫The total height of the burial chamber is 8.84 meters.

⚫During the excavations in the years 1833 until 1837, the kurgan was opened.
⚫It contained only remnants of a wooden sarcophagus, so it was probably robbed long ago.
⚫Christian symbols carved on the walls suggest that the grave rooms served early Christians as a place of refuge and as a sanctuary.

node.text:
🔘The Hanging Pillar of Lepakshi Temple🔘
⚫It is located in the village of Lepakshi, District of Andhra Pradesh, India.

⚫It was built in the 16th century and is also known as Veerabhadra temple.
⚫Among the 70 stone pillars, there is one that hangs from the ceiling!

⚫The base of the pillar barely touches the ground and is possible to pass objects such as a thin sheet of paper or a piece of cloth from one side to the other.

⚫The temple features many sculptures of god, goddesses, dancers and musicians, and hundreds of paintings all over the walls, columns and ceiling.

⚫At the front of the temple is a large bull, the mount of Shiva, which is carved from a single block of stone, and could be one of the largest of its type in the world.(last pic)

node.text:
🔘The theatre of Hierapolis🔘
⚫Hierapolis ("Holy City") was an ancient Greek city located on hot springs in classical Phrygia, Turkey.

⚫The theatre at Hierapolis was built in the second century AD under the Roman Emperor Hadrian during a period of extensive rebuilding following a devastating earthquake in 60 AD.
⚫It was later renovated under Septimus Severus (193-211 AD).

⚫The facade is 300 feet (91 m) long, the full extent of which remains standing.
⚫In the cavea there are 45 rows of seats, recent reconstruction efforts have restored most of the cavea which could accommodate approximately 15,000 people.

⚫At this time, the scaenae frons was modified and decorated with elaborate limestone and marble carvings.
⚫Although the exterior is relatively unassuming as viewed from the front, the interior contains one of Anatolia's most complete and best-preserved collection of Greco-Roman theatre decorations.

⚫In 343 AD the scaenae was renovated and the orchestra was altered so that it could hold aquatic displays.
⚫In the later years of the Roman Empire the orchestra was converted into a cellar.
